concepts.name: The Stack
concepts.summary: Where spells and abilities wait to resolve
concepts.content:
When you cast a spell or activate an ability, it goes on 'the stack' - a zone where things wait to happen. The stack resolves in LIFO order (last in, first out), meaning the most recent spell/ability resolves first.

This is why 'in response' works: if you cast Lightning Bolt and your opponent casts Counterspell, the Counterspell goes on the stack on top of your Bolt. The Counterspell resolves first, countering your Bolt before it ever resolves.

Things that DON'T use the stack:
- Playing a land (can't be responded to)
- Mana abilities (tapping lands for mana)
- Turning face-down creatures face up
- Static abilities (they're always 'on')

concepts.name: Priority
concepts.summary: Determines who can act at any given moment
concepts.content:
Priority is the 'permission to act' that passes between players. Only the player with priority can cast spells or activate abilities.

How priority works:
1. Active player (whose turn it is) gets priority first in each phase
2. After they act (or pass), priority goes to the next player
3. When all players pass in succession with nothing on the stack, the phase ends
4. When all players pass with something on the stack, the top item resolves

You automatically pass priority when you have nothing to do. The game doesn't stop constantly - it flows naturally unless someone wants to respond.

concepts.name: Combat
concepts.content:
Combat happens in steps:

1. Beginning of Combat - Last chance to tap/remove creatures before attacks

2. Declare Attackers - Active player chooses which creatures attack (they tap). Creatures with summoning sickness can't attack.

3. Declare Blockers - Defending player chooses how to block. One blocker can only block one attacker, but multiple blockers can block the same attacker.

4. Combat Damage - Damage is dealt simultaneously (except first strike). Attacking creature deals damage to blockers; unblocked creatures deal damage to the defending player/planeswalker.

5. End of Combat - Cleanup phase for combat

Key points:
- Blocked creatures deal damage to blockers, not the player (even if blocker dies before damage)
- First strike creatures deal damage in a separate, earlier step
- Trample lets excess damage 'spill over' to the player

concepts.name: Turn Structure
concepts.summary: The phases and steps of a turn
concepts.content:
Each turn has these phases:

1. BEGINNING PHASE
   - Untap (untap your permanents, no spells allowed)
   - Upkeep (triggers that say 'at the beginning of your upkeep')
   - Draw (draw a card)

2. FIRST MAIN PHASE
   - Cast any spell type
   - Play a land (once per turn total)
   - Activate abilities

3. COMBAT PHASE
   - Beginning of Combat
   - Declare Attackers
   - Declare Blockers  
   - Combat Damage (first strike, then regular)
   - End of Combat

4. SECOND MAIN PHASE
   - Same as first main phase
   - Good for casting creatures after combat

5. ENDING PHASE
   - End Step (triggers that say 'at the beginning of your end step')
   - Cleanup (discard to hand size, damage wears off)

concepts.name: Mana & Casting Costs
concepts.content:
Mana is the resource you use to cast spells. It comes in 5 colors plus colorless:

{W} White - Plains
{U} Blue - Islands  
{B} Black - Swamps
{R} Red - Mountains
{G} Green - Forests
{C} Colorless - Special lands/artifacts

Reading mana costs:
- {2}{R}{R} means pay 2 mana of any type + 2 red mana (4 total)
- {X}{G} means pay X mana of any type + 1 green
- Generic mana (numbers) can be paid with any color
- Colored symbols MUST be paid with that exact color

Mana Value (formerly CMC):
The total mana required. {2}{R}{R} has mana value 4. {X} counts as 0 except on the stack.

concepts.name: Card Types
concepts.summary: The different kinds of cards in Magic
concepts.content:
PERMANENT TYPES (stay on battlefield):
- Creature - Has power/toughness, can attack and block
- Artifact - Colorless items, equipment, vehicles
- Enchantment - Ongoing magical effects
- Planeswalker - Allies with loyalty abilities
- Land - Produces mana, one per turn

NON-PERMANENT TYPES:
- Instant - Cast any time, then goes to graveyard
- Sorcery - Cast only on your main phase, empty stack

SUPERTYPES:
- Legendary - Only one copy can be on your battlefield
- Basic - Can have any number in deck (lands)
- Snow - Has the snow supertype for synergies

SUBTYPES:
- Creature subtypes: Human, Elf, Goblin, etc.
- Land subtypes: Plains, Island, Swamp, Mountain, Forest
- Artifact subtypes: Equipment, Vehicle, etc.

concepts.name: Zones
concepts.summary: Where cards can exist during a game
concepts.content:
Library - Your deck. Cards are face down. Draw from the top.

Hand - Cards you've drawn. Private zone (opponents can't see). Maximum 7 cards at end of turn.

Battlefield - Where permanents exist. Public zone. Everything is face-up (usually).

Graveyard - Your discard pile. Public zone - anyone can look. Many cards interact with the graveyard.

Exile - 'Removed from game' zone. Cards here are usually gone permanently unless they specify otherwise.

Stack - Where spells and abilities wait to resolve. Public zone.

Command Zone - For commanders, emblems, and other special objects.

concepts.name: Color Identity
concepts.summary: Which colors a card belongs to (especially for Commander)
concepts.content:
Color identity includes:
1. Colors in the mana cost
2. Colors of any mana symbols in the rules text
3. Color indicators (colored dots)

Examples:
- Alesha, Who Smiles at Death is a red creature but has {W}{B} in its ability, so its color identity is red-white-black
- Transguild Courier has no colored mana symbols but its color indicator shows all 5 colors

In Commander, your deck can only contain cards within your commander's color identity. A colorless commander means only colorless cards.

Basic lands have color identity matching the mana they produce (Plains = white identity).

concepts.name: Instant Speed
concepts.summary: When you can cast spells and activate abilities
concepts.content:
INSTANT SPEED (any time you have priority):
- Instant spells
- Cards with Flash
- Activated abilities (unless they say otherwise)
- Triggered abilities (they trigger automatically)

SORCERY SPEED (only during your main phase, empty stack):
- Sorcery spells
- Creature spells (usually)
- Other permanents (artifacts, enchantments, planeswalkers)
- Abilities that say 'activate only as a sorcery'
- Special actions like playing a land

Timing Tricks:
- Cast creatures with Flash at end of opponent's turn
- Activate planeswalkers only at sorcery speed
- Equipment's Equip ability is sorcery speed

concepts.name: Summoning Sickness
concepts.content:
Creatures can't attack or use abilities with the tap symbol ({T}) on the turn they come under your control. This is called 'summoning sickness.'

What summoning sickness PREVENTS:
- Attacking
- Activating abilities that require {T} or {Q}

What summoning sickness DOES NOT PREVENT:
- Blocking
- Activating abilities without {T}
- Being tapped by other effects
- Using static abilities

Haste removes summoning sickness, letting creatures attack and tap immediately.

Note: Summoning sickness cares about continuous control, not entering. If you gain control of an opponent's creature, it has summoning sickness unless it has haste.

concepts.name: State-Based Actions
concepts.summary: Automatic game rules that are always checked
concepts.content:
State-based actions (SBAs) are rules the game checks constantly. They don't use the stack and can't be responded to.

Common SBAs:
- Creature with 0 or less toughness dies
- Creature with lethal damage marked dies
- Player with 0 or less life loses
- Player with 10+ poison counters loses
- Player who can't draw loses
- Legendary rule (keep one, sacrifice the rest)
- Planeswalker with 0 loyalty is put into graveyard
- +1/+1 and -1/-1 counters cancel out

SBAs happen before any player gets priority. This is why damage and toughness reduction work differently - damage is marked and checked by SBAs, while -X/-X actually changes toughness.

concepts.name: Targeting
concepts.summary: How spells and abilities choose what they affect
concepts.content:
If a spell or ability says 'target,' you must choose legal targets when you cast/activate it.

Targeting rules:
1. Targets must be legal when chosen AND when the spell resolves
2. If all targets become illegal, the spell is countered
3. Hexproof, Shroud, and Protection can make things untargetable
4. 'Each,' 'all,' and 'any number of' are NOT targeting

Examples:
- 'Destroy target creature' - targets (can be countered by hexproof)
- 'Destroy all creatures' - doesn't target (ignores hexproof)
- 'Choose a creature' - doesn't target (sneaky wording)

This matters for protection, hexproof, and 'whenever targeted' triggers.

concepts.name: Replacement Effects
concepts.summary: Effects that modify how events happen
concepts.content:
Replacement effects change how something happens. They use words like 'instead' or 'as [X] enters.'

Examples:
- 'If you would draw a card, instead draw two' - replaces draws
- 'As [creature] enters, choose a color' - replaces entering
- 'If damage would be dealt, prevent it' - replaces damage

Key rules:
1. Each replacement effect applies only once per event
2. The affected player/controller chooses order if multiple apply
3. Replacement effects don't trigger abilities (they change the event itself)

Common replacement effects:
- Prevention effects
- 'Enters with counters' effects
- 'If would die, instead exile' effects
- Doubling effects

concepts.name: Triggered vs Activated
concepts.summary: Two types of abilities and how they work
concepts.content:
TRIGGERED ABILITIES:
- Start with 'when,' 'whenever,' or 'at'
- Happen automatically when condition is met
- Go on the stack and can be responded to
- Example: 'When this creature dies, draw a card'

ACTIVATED ABILITIES:
- Written as [cost]: [effect]
- You choose when to activate (and pay the cost)
- Go on the stack and can be responded to
- Example: '{2}{B}: Target creature gets -1/-1'

Mana abilities are special:
- Activated abilities that produce mana
- DON'T use the stack
- Can't be responded to
- Example: '{T}: Add {G}'

Static abilities are always 'on' and don't use the stack:
- Example: 'Creatures you control have +1/+1'

concepts.name: Commander Rules
concepts.summary: Special rules for the Commander format
concepts.content:
Deck Construction:
- 100 cards exactly (including commander)
- Only one copy of each card (except basic lands)
- All cards must be within commander's color identity
- Commander starts in the command zone

Gameplay:
- Start with 40 life
- Commander can be cast from command zone
- Commander tax: costs {2} more each time cast from command zone
- If commander would go to graveyard or exile, you may put it in command zone instead
- 21 combat damage from a single commander = that player loses

Multiplayer:
- Usually 4 players, free-for-all
- Politics and alliances are part of the game
- Games tend to be longer and more casual
